review_body: In a nutshell American Airlines really inconvenienced me, so I got stuck flying into Nareda then taking the bus to Haneda with a 16 hour layover. On the bus trip I found this gem of a place to stay. Very affordable, spoke English, super clean, showers and spa available with your room rental. I couldn't be more happy with my experience. Almost worth the price just to leave your bags somewhere for a few hours. If you get in after all the restaurants close you may still purchase food and even beer in their vending machines. It is set up kind of strange where you get your own cube, and you are only separated from other patrons by a vinyl door, but everyone is very respectful and quiet (I felt bad making noise by zipping up my bag).They provide you with everything neccessary for the shower/spa to include, toothbrush and paste, towels and washcloths, pajamas and slippers. The showers are individual, but the spa and dressing areas are open (like a locker room). This isn't really an issue as everyone keeps to themselves as they're getting ready.Hands down I would stay here again! For ¥6800 you just cant do better. And the best part is it's in the terminal so you don't need to rush to get to the airport.

My international flight is at 6am and I should arrive at the airport before 4am so I choose to stay in the cabin hotel for shower and a quick nap. They provide everything you need including towel, shampoo, pajama, etc. I was in a hurry so did not try the onsen. Definitely the perfect place to stay for catching early flights.

My two adult sons and myself were arriving on an international flight at 1am. It was going to be very expensive to get into Tokyo at 2/2.30am (there are several flights arriving at once) so we chose to book in at First Cabin Haneda as the only way to Tokyo was taxi and then paying full nights accommodation. I found their website a little difficult to book on but an email straight to them sorted a booking immediately. You need to get to Terminal 1 (domestic) after arriving on an international flight but the taxi concierge spoke perfect English and organised the trip for us on the spot. The taxi driver even waited after we rang the after hours bell to ensure we got in okay. Once in we were given keys to immaculately clean ‘pod’ style rooms (men one side of reception, women the other). Rooms were equipped with pyjamas (I’m a size 16 and they fitted comfortably) towels, slippers, tissues, dimmable lights, air conditioning, headphones for TV, toothbrush & paste, hanging space, safe and beautifully clean and crisp white bedding. The shared bathroom is equipped with face cleanser, hair dryers, soap, moisturiser, all in a very clean space with showers and seated areas in front of well lit mirrors. It is a very respectful, quiet area and even though the pods around you are all occupied it is very peaceful and relaxed.You can stay until 10am and there is a lounge with comfortable seating and refreshments if you need to stay longer. There is of course free wifi.We loved the experience as our first taste of Japan and it’s wonderful uniqueness. Highly recommended as a late flight arrival option.

I stayed here because I need to catch an early flight at 6:30am depart from the international terminal. This hotel is located in domestic terminal 1 which makes me quite struggle before making the reservation. However they offered me shuttle service at 4:05am ONLY for First Cabin users (the normal earliest shuttle is at 5am)! It was thoughtful and super great and I hope more and more travellers know about that;) They better put it on the website as well!How surprised that they equipped with a hot spa! Though I’m not sure if it is a onsen but it was great to have it before leaving Japan! I’ll check in earlier if I know they have it in advance!The only thing made my stay imperfect, the cabin was too hot. I have chosen the first class cain but still sweated after get into my sleep and always woke me up.

For what it is, it's great. Do not expect the comfort and/or luxuries of a hotel. This is a capsule hotel in the airport. It is convenient, and that is why we booked it (early flight the next morning). Amenities were fabulous - hair dryers, hair straighteners, hair curlers. Shiseido branded toiletries, and plenty of them. Lots of space to do your hair/makeup. Provided PJs, slippers, towels. Everything you need for a short stay. Staff were helpful and friendly and stored our bigger luggage while we kept our smaller bags with us, which we could lock away in our capsules. Beds were hard but no harder than the other hotels we stayed at in the other Japanese cities. The only downside is the noise. Indeed, as others have mentioned, you can hear everything. Someone near us was snoring most of the night and there is little to no sound barrier. Earplugs are available at the front desk but in the middle of the night the last thing you want to do is trek out there, half asleep. Would stay here again for a night before a flight.

Besides being a part of the airport (probably the one of the reasons why you choose it), it's a very modern and clean capsule hotel with very attentive staff.There are large and small compartments, with the large one having enough space to fit one luggage on the floor and a small round table. The small one is basically a twin bed without that extra floor space. There are no USB outlets, so bring your own adapters. You will hear people walking around but people all try to be quite and are considerate. You can't lock the door but they provide a luggage storage facility. For large room, you can lock your belongings in a small drawer under the bed.Bathroom facilities are clean and modern. There is a small common area with tables.It's situated within the Aeroplaza which is literally minutes of walk away from the train station and T1.

If your looking for a clean, convenient pod hotel this is the place! Warm and welcoming staff. The hotel provides everything you would need during your stay. The on-site 24 hour communal bath is also a huge bonus and great when travelling!

There are a lot of things I loved about this place. The front desk was very helpful and professional, and the entire sleeping area was very quiet. The bathrooms were extremely clean, and there was a spa area that was extremely relaxing. The sleeping pod was very spacious with plenty of lights and storage areas. However, I'm a side sleeper, and the bed was extremely hard. I kept waking up and had an aching shoulder in the morning. This hotel is amazing, but I definitely need to sleep in a somewhat softer bed next time.

If you are in the transit from haneda airport to narita airport. Its late at night, where can you stay ? I recomend you can consider first cabin hotel.Only at night after 10pm the food stalls and restaurant are closed. You may have instand noodles, bread, ice cream at the vanding machines in the first cabin. The hotel facilities are very good. Although its share wash room and bathroom, no worry they are so well maintained and very clean.Just few steps walk outside the hotel there are airport limousine bus ticketing machines which you can buy the limousine bus ticket from haneda to narita airport easily.I feel no stress on this arrangement when i travel with my families in group of 8 person include senior persons.

I had an early check in & flight from Handea Airport so booked a room (pod) at ‘First Cabin’. This was my first experience in a pod type hotel. Easy to find in Terminal 1 (Domestic) well signposted with a well organised check-in.Very different from a normal hotel as you are effectively in a small pod - there are 2 types a business class pod which is the width of a queen size bed (wall to wall) a TV, small shelf small locker & a roller door NOTE there are no locks on the door! I had the first class pod which is a bit larger with a queen size bed a small table and 3 feet of space between th the bed & the wall Large TV (in Japanese) small locker under the bed. You are supplied with a bath towel, hand towel, slippers & PJ’s, you are asked to refrain from talking or making any noise when in your pod you are given headphones for the tv, you are also not allowed to eat or drink in the pod!There is a small lounge next to reception should you wish to eat/drink there are the normal vending machine as well.The toilets & showers are outside the room from the pods, The Men’s pod are totally separated from the Women’s pods there are no family pods.I think the concept is great & works well in an airport that has a lot of early flights & can take a long time to get to from the centre of Tokyo, it can also be booked by the hour if you have a long layover

review_body: This is really convenient for late or early flights. I stayed here twice as I had a late arriving flight and an early departing flight. It is in the domestic terminal 1 so you have to catch the free shuttle bus to get to the international terminal. The bus stop is directly opposite the entrance to FirstCabin. The beds were a little hard and there is not really space to put your luggage other than leaving it in the corridor outside your cabin. It was clean and comfortable and really convenient.

Everything was superb! It was very clean and facilities are great. Plus they provide a morning call service which was very useful for me. Their vending machines are great and not overprice. Overall it's been an amazing experience.

Took the night flight and arrived Japan, I checked in First Cabin Haneda Terminal 1 at 3am. Front desk staff are polite. And it is a clean and nice place allow you to take a short rest and to have refreshing shower or bath. However, you must be a easy sleeper or you don't need to sleep, because there are always people walking around, slippers and luggage moving / hitting on the raised floor produces noise a lot. And the housekeeper ran in the corridor after every customers left their capsule room was extremely annoying.

What a neat experience to stay in such a place! Booking was a little difficult because everything online is either in Japanese or oddly translated English, but I powered through. The confirmation email was in Japanese too, but I used my Google Translate app to translate it which helped. Check in was easy, my pod was clean and comfortable, the bathroom was clean, and the pod room was quiet. It was a perfect place to spend a long layover. I would definitely stay again.

Need a place to shower and have a quick nap before my flight due in 8 hours time. Saw the other reviews about issue on booking so I asked the airport information counter to assist. Was told they still have room and I need to do a walk in.Took the 3hrs stay (minimum) for ¥3000. You can pay ¥1000 for ever extra hour used if you exceeded your check out time.Have a shower which I was dying for and took a 2 hour nap.Be mindful if you are a light sleeper as the cabin are just partition laid along a walk way. Can be noisy if there are people walking and dragging their luggage.Else, it is a cheap way to have a quick rest and refresh without the needs to travel too far away from the airport. Transport fee is also saved as the shuttle service between the terminal is free.

Came here with my sister when our flight got in after the last public transport into Tokyo had left for the evening (it was around 11.30 p.m.). We paid to upgrade to the slightly larger capsules. Shared bathroom facilities were great and it had a sauna. Capsules and bathroom facilities were split into male and female. Not much in the way of food to buy apart from in a vending machine so perhaps bring something with you. Pajamas were provided. Only issue for me was that I was constantly woken up by people walking past, unpacking their bags, leaving in the morning etc., so I can't say I had a good nights sleep.

This was not a hotel but a resting place with personal cabins. The cabins, under the Japanese law, cannot be locked as the place was not categorised as a hotel.Nevertheless, this was actually a very good place to rest and re-organize. I had about 6 hours to spare before catching my flight at 1.30 am. All the amenities are shared here but they were kept spick and span. There was a hot spring pool, shower rooms, toilets, spacious wash basin for personal grooming (I am not sure about the women's side as they are separated) and even a set of washing machine &dryer. Towels and toiletries were all provided for, plus a set of T-shirt and pants to change into.The place is located right inside Haneda Terminal 1. There were plenty of restaurants, eateries, bakeries and shops to meet our needs. Also, one just need to go to Gate 8 (just outside the entrance to First Cabin) to hop onto the free shuttle to the international terminal, or terminal 2.The room could not be locked but only a louvre to latch onto (again, requirement of Japanese law) but, for the bigger room, there is a big drawer under the bed which could be locked. One can just store the valuables inside. Anyway, the place was secured and I would say it was fairly safe. Occasionally, one might hear people walking past or talking but generally, the place was pretty quiet and good enough for a nap.

Sometimes I arrive in Tokyo Haneda very early (5am), while my hotel room further up North is only available at 3pm. After a sleepless flight (nope, I really can't sleep on a plane), I really have no wish to go wander the streets of Tokyo, but instead prefer some sleep. First Cabin is ideal for that. It's a capsule hotel, don't expect a full blown hotel experience. As I'm sleeping there on a somewhat strange hour (while all others are leaving), there is a bit more movement in the corridors between the capsules, still a good sleep is perfectly possible. The mattress is a bit hard. For me that's perfect, but be warned. There's showers and a spa, amenities are made available. Perfect, actually, though I must say the hygiene could be a bit better. For Japanese standards, the maintenance is a bit sub-optimal. But it's small details only, like for instance dust nests on the rack with baskets next to the shower. First Cabin is situated in Domestic Flights Terminal 1, which can be reached in minutes by free shuttle. For me a very useful service.

Spent a few hours for a short stay after an early arrival (5am) Haneda airport. This capsule hotel is in domestic terminal - easy to catch free shuttle bus, takes 5mins. The hotel was easy to find, and easy at reception to book a few hours. They have special short stay plans for their "first class" cabins - bit more space. It was relatively quiet and I managed to get to sleep easily. Really helps! Also enjoyed the novelty of staying in a capsule. Very clean and well equipped bathroom and shower facilities

Based on the recommendation of a friend, I booked here during my brief transit in Haneda. The check-in was efficient and fast, accommodation and facilities were clean. This is a safe and convenient place to stay and would highly recommend to friends.

As a one-off experience staying in a capsule hotel was fun and different.The “room” or pod was conveniently located in Haneda airport, was clean and quite comfortable, the WiFi’s was fine and the washing facilities more than adequate. It was also well priced for a single traveller.However I would very much describe this as a novelty experience and given the choice between here and most standard airport hotels, I think I would chose the latter.

My flight was delayed and I contacted them via email and they were very quick to reply and assure me that they would hold my booking. Their email also contained all the information I needed to get there late at night.Once I arrived they were friendly and the whole check in process was efficient and quick. They offer earplugs and headphones (to watch the TV in your room) for free as well as an adaptor to charge your phone. They also asked if I would like a wake up call in the morning which I thought was great.For a layover stay I would highly recommend staying here :)

I had a late flight into Haneda and knew that I'd be too tired to do anything.I booked online and they sent a confirmation email a few days before I was due to check-in.Great little first experience in capsule-style hotel accommodation. You'll pay 6000 ¥ for a first class cabin, although I probably didn't need that 'luxury'.You'll get supplied with all the basics including slippers. I especially loved the onsen/spa after a long plane flight.I caught the last free shuttle bus from Haneda International airport at 11.56pm. There are food vending machines in the lounge if you all the food outlets are closed.Sleeping areas are single gender, as are the washroom facilities.Checkout is 10am and there is a post office (with ATMS) and coffee shops to get you started in the morning.

This is an ideal quick stop if you have to fill time between arriving and next leg. Clean, comfortable sleeping option, excellent shower facility. As a larger(ish) guy I was well accommodated in both places space-wise. Easy to nap, refresh and transit.

I had booked a first class cabin because my flight from Taiwan arrived late and I thought that the place could suit my needs. The place is easy to find and super clean. I had a first class cabin with some 4square meters. Bed was OK and enough room for my bag. Pretty nice.... But, the first drawback was that the bathroom was one floor lower, cabin couldn't be locked and worse, light on in the corridors all night which prevented me from sleeping. Last point, I they ask you to be quiet but there were people speaking aloud all night and when I asked them to silence, they didn't bother. Paying some €55/¥7,000 is a rip off.

I arrived late into Haneda and didn't want to face Tokyo transport late at night. I opted for this hotel which you need to note is in the domestic airport. There is a free shuttle from the international airport which runs regularly.Hotel is very professionally run. I had a first class cabin and it was very comfortable and had quite a few extras. The rooms can't be locked but this did not cause any issue as a lockable drawer is provided. The bathroom facilities were excellent.

Always fully booked. So it is better to have reservation. I checked in about 12am and stay for about 4 hours to catch a 6am flight. It is better to prepare some snack since there is no convenient store is open at that time. The shower room and spa place are clean. Business cabin cost 5000yen which is a twin size bed room with curtain door. No space for your luggage, you need to check in your luggage at the front desk. First cabin costs 7000yen, you get a bit bigger space. It is quiet but you definitely can hear sound since there is no real door existed.

With about eight hours to kill in Tokyo I was tired and got a recommendation from the info desk at terminal 1. I'd never stayed at one of these places and was pleasantly surprised. I opted for the bigger room-like capsule at JPY1000 per hour. It was clean, quiet and comfortable. I made good use of the shower and onsen-like hot tub to soothe away my travel aches. Wi-fi was good, TV was all Japanese. This place is perfect for a long connection or stopover. There are plenty of restaurants in the terminal and decent vending machines by reception. The long soak in the tub was the factor X. Recommended.

Late night arrival made this a perfect stop to rest before getting on with our holiday. Friendly staff at reception to explain the concept to a couple of cabin virgins made this process much easier, before being thrown into the fantastically strange world of cabin sleeping. Although obviously small, the cabins are comfortable, clean and private enough to feel separated from the outside (ear plugs at reception, happily help to drown out the more aggressive of sleepers).Lovely showers and a communal spa add to the experience and made this short stay, a very pleasant one!

I have stayed here five times now. The facilities are simple but good. I travel alone so don't need to worry too much about using the lounge room. It can be a little noisy as people come and go, so I recommend earplugs. This time the bathroom floor was very slippery and a bit dirty, so I was disappointed. I hope they will take greater care of this.

We booked into this location owing to the fact that our flight got into Tokyo International station at 22.30 and I expected it would take me an hour to get through immigration, so I did not want to spend much money and it was just a brief sleep to allow me to get a good start the next day.Firstly, it will take 20 minutes from the international arrivals to domestic terminal one with the free shuttle bus. The bus drops you off at the main entrance that is closest to the hotel entrance inside the terminal building.Checkin was smooth and finding the cabin was easy, in effect it's a large hall with cabins slotted in to build a structure in the room.You can't talk in the room, set your alarm, play music or watch TV out loud, you must use headphones and if you want to be woke then you can let reception know and they will wake you.When I got to my first class cabin ( almost double the size of a standard cabin) it looked clean, if not a little dusty. I had a bed side table, TV, pillow and booster pillow/cushion along with a small blanket, not big enough to cover the whole length of the bed.I decided to try the Spa (communal bath) it is open for 21 hours a day, closing at 9.30am for cleaning and sadly it seems that this is the only time it gets cleaned. The floor between the Onsen and the showers was so slime that we found we had to wash the floor so we would not slip on it, we then had to use the separate private showers to wash our feet after.The private shower area has carpet, so this is also nasty given everyone walks on it when wet.After the slime experience it was time for bed, I was looking forward to it but the bed was rock hard, cover thin and not big enough to cover me and it was so cold. I between all of this you could hear other people opening the sliding divider, walking up and down and of course opening suitcases to throw things around it and make as much racket as they could looking for things.Altogether this was not a great experience and I would suggest that if you are a party of 2 or more and are coming in from the international terminal then you should just book into a real hotel that is cleaned more often. Such a shame this place don't do a better job of checking people in and out to allow others to get a better nights sleep and also a shame that cleaning of the spa is only done once a day as this is simply not enough to keep it clean. This was a bit surprise given the high standards in Japan.

More akin to a business man's hostel, this is a very Japanese style semi-private hostel-like experience. The room has a non-locking curtain and a high level of respectful quiet is expected (unlike Euro hostels). The bathrooms have bidets to wash your private parts, and there are shower stalls for those too shy to use the onsen. Big mistake! The onsen is a typical sex segregated all nude shower on a small seat preceding a large communal hot bath. Quiet nice! I recommend both shower and onsen wash just for the experience and fun of being in Japan.They track the loaner clothing called "cabin wear" although I wasn't offered any, perhaps due to my gaijin size or short stay. They have a luggage storage area for customers so I'm not sure what the other reviewer was complaining about: I used it while I went to lunch and was issued a luggage check card. I suspect it may have been due to the language barrier, so be prepared to patiently and politely run your requests through Google translate (or an understanding fellow patron) for a good experience. A shared area with TV, snacks, beer vending machines for off hours. A far cry from anything in the USA.

We had reserved the place through a local contact so that we can stay the night before getting our connecting flight to Nagasaki the next morning. I assumed it was a hotel and had accepted JPY 5300 per room. When we arrived, it turned out to be a capsule hotel. I was shocked to see what we got against our payment. One of it's unpleasant features was it's black painted walls. The feeling was like a transit station to cemetery. The capsules didn't even have a proper and secure door and it was only a sort of curtain which could be taken down to 20 cm level of the ground. I will make sure to never make such a mistake to sleep in such a place.

One of the main attraction of this hotel was the location. I could stay overnight, leave my luggage, go out for sightseeing, and come back to pick up the luggage and head to the airport.They do NOT allow you to leave luggage! Even after confirming over the phone that I would be allowed to leave luggage, they REFUSED to keep them on site. THIS is a BIG deal breaker! ANY OTHER hotels in the area allow you to leave luggage. STAY AWAY! I won't be coming back to this hotel!

There are a few buses still running in mid night but only reach to some popular places in city center. First cabin hotel is a good option if you wanna take a rest. Be aware that first cabin locate in terminal 1 but international flight land in international terminal. Taxi is easy option to get there and cost around Yen1500. Do not walking to there cause it is dark on the way and a little bit far. There are 2 room choice. First cabin (size is just fit a single bed) is smaller than business cabin. Bed is comfortable and shower area is clean and they even provide some sweet things like lotion, makeup remover.....The other sweet thing is they can give you morning call if you ask. There will be one staff to knock your bed curtain to wake you up in case you miss flight.

Great space and location-we didn't have to go far to find it or out of the building in the middle of winter Thank God! Even better-the capsules are little rooms almost with your own tv and earfones! So great!! And a lovely little onsen too- reasonably priced! My only issue was food and no great restaurants near by for late hours-would be best to prep food in advance! Lovely service as well.

I arrived at Haneda at 5am after an overnight flight from Shanghai. I needed to get some rest, so I checked in here and had 3 hours to relax and sleep a bit. They have a 'morning' plan that gives you 3 hours, and it was perfect for me. The mini room (not a capsule) was extremely clean and the facilities were clean and modern, as well. I highly recommend this place for either a rest or for a full night. Probably best to have some experience with Japanese culture and Japanese language.

review_body: Literally just checked out of the First Cabin at HND. My boyfriend and I had a long layover from Tokyo to Okinawa and decided to check this out.You can get 3 hours for 3000 yen ($30 USD). Perfect time for a nap and shower to refresh yourself!!!! First Class capsule is Very comfortable, clean and cozy quarters. You have enough room for 1-2 large luggage but if you have smaller room I think they can store it for you.Bathrooms were clean and offered Shesido products for hair, face and body. They give you toothbrush and toothpaste as well. Toilets, showers, and spa with steam room. My bf said he took a bath but I didn't see one lol -- didn't look though! Highly recommend and I would prefer to stay here if ever experience lengthy layover again. So worth the money -- I feel so refreshed!!!!

We arrived at night because we we had an early flight the next day. Very easy check In as we had booked well in advance ( absolutely essential as it gets booked up early)! You have your own cabin and a good sized bed which was very comfortable though it's shared toilet and shower area but women are separate. This wasn't a problem and everything is very clean and toiletries and hairdryer available. Suitable for any age range if seniors are worried! Nice communal area for drinks etc. Fantastic experience! You can't go wrong!

Very convenient for either late arrivals or early take-offs. However, watch out that there is a free shuttle bus between international and domestic terminals but it doesn't run 24 hours - a taxi take about 5 minute but costs nearly 1600Y!Good facilities, but disappointed about lack of water drinking facilities.Cabins are small, but ideal for just a sleep.Most of the capsules are all within the same room / floor which means that air circulation is poor and its very noisy as people are getting up / arriving at all sorts of hours! Definitely not for the light sleepers.

I just love this place... Nevermind the shoebox size room, that's not the point in staying here... Its the experience!!! Japanese hospitality at its best! It's located in the 1F domestic terminal of Haneda Airport... 7 mins by bus to the international terminal. It's so unique in its concept that you'll only find in Japan. This is ideal for solo travelers or group of friends or families without small children. Not for honeymooners lol!!! Check in was smooth... The explanation brief and concise. One thing about Japan that I learned was that most extras are free like plug adapters, earplugs, fast pass/fast track at Disneysea. They provided it free of charge. I would highly recommend the First Class.. It's an extra JPY1000 or £6.00 than the business class. You get the extra space which I'm sure you'll totally appreciate. Men and women are separate areas. But the lounge area where you can eat, talk, smoke is mix, but there's also a women only lounge. Don't ask me why that's the case but that's the way it is :-), besides there's no talking in the sleeping/cabin area. I was given a card to swipe or tap to enter the women's area then a locker key. The cabins: the first class cabin is very functional. It has a table, a locker or a drawer with a lock, dim lighting and a huge tv for a small room, I think it's a 37in tv lol! I was provided with knee length shorts and a shirt, a bath & a hand towel, wash cloth, toothbrush/paste, slippers. I was wondering at the lounge earlier when I'm having my fag and drink why was some wearing the same clothes... I thought they're a group of students... But it was the clothes provided so we be comfortable... Now the spa/ bathrooms / vanity / toilets... The bathroom comprises of a shower cubicle with the strongest water pressure ever hahaha.. The shampoo, conditioner, shower gels and facial soap are all SHISEIDO. Like very impressive! There's a basket rack outside the shower to put your stuff in. The spa has this sort of wading pool, we're you can relax... Water is heated. The vanity area... Huge mirrors, chairs and stools, facial creams, handsoaps lotions ( they have this unique clear watery lotion ... I'll try to find it next time I visit Japan ) again all by shisheido. They have hair dryer per table, curling / straightening irons etc. The toilet... Is a separate area and you need to use the toilet slippers inside... Cleanest people ever!Lounge is a nice cozy place with a long table and chairs for eating, sofas and lounge chairs for relaxing, books, newspapers, magazines and bar stools. It has different vending machines for drinks and hot food. A smoking area. Charging area... A washer and dryer is also provided but requires coins. If you got lots of luggage, they store it for you. No extra cost of course. Restaurants outside the hotel abs inside the domestic terminal building closes at 23.00H. They provide wake up call as no one is allowed to have alarms inside the sleeping area. So enjoy and explore their website... And when you book, they don't ask for credit card info .. Just name email gender and you pay upon check in.

Very convenient as we were able to do a late check-in close to midnight. Shuttle was also available for free from the international airport.Staff was helpful and spoke in English.Bath facilities were shared but very clean. Room and bed was small but good for value. Men and women sleep in different dorms respectively for safety as there are room doors / locks. You can keep you belongings inside a small lockable drawer which is in your room.Overall, this hotel is great for a short stay and convenient. After we check-out in the morning, we walked across to the bus ticket counter to head to town.

I tried this hotel because my girlfriend had wanted to try a capsule hotel while we were in Japan. Since we had an early flight the next morning, she booked us into the First Cabin Luxury Capsule hotel at Haneda Airport. These were not what you would imagine a capsule hotel to be, crawling into a 4x4x8ft capsule and sleeping. These were essentially a tiny room with sliding doors (with a gap at the bottom and top). The economy ones ~$50 had the width of the bed of the entire room, while the luxury capsules, ~$60 were slightly wider with a space to walk into your room and to place your luggage on the floor. I stayed in the luxury capsule as we thought it would be easier if one of us had the luggage for the night. The rooms are pretty bare boned as was expected, but they serve its purpose. There were also pajamas provided for you; mine were a bit small on me, sized medium for 5’10” 163lb. There was also a very nice locker styled bathroom with multiple sinks with beauty lights, several nice showers and even a spa room that I did not use. As for my night, I unfortunately did not get much sleep. Due to the design of the rooms, they are sliding doors without a lock and a air gap at the top and bottom of the sliding door which allows hallway noise and light, as well as nose from your neighbors to seep in very noticeably. I had the unfortunately luck of having someone near my room be a very loud snorer, and it kept me up all night. Overall, the facilities were nice, and the rooms were cheap. Unfortunately, if you are a light sleeper, you may want to reconsider as it’s a luck of the draw if you’re there the same time as someone who snores, otherwise if you are a heavier sleeper or can wear earplugs, this might be an option you would want to consider.

Stayed here for a quick layover at Haneda airport. The location of this hotel is great for transit hotel right at T1, so great for both domestic and international travelers. The hotel itself is an height end capsule hotel with two different types of room. Business and First. I had the first class room with was like a mini hotel room without bathroom. And the female bathroom was nice and with basic(standard) personal care and skin care product. And PJ ALSO PROVIDED at this hotel. Since this still is a capsule hotel that soundproofing is not at nice as the traditional hotel so sleep quality could be a issue at night. And this hotel is not for family and couple, since each area is single gender only and children under the age of 12 is not welcomed.

1. Convenient , next to free inter-terminal shuttle bus and just few minutes from train to hotel2. nice bath room and hot spring room3. tidiness 99% at toilet , bathroom, bed4. staff friendly and nice5. but cannot set alarm as it is not allowed. Staff can wake you up instead of alarm6. Air-condition is not so good. It makes me feeling hot even in April7. It's good place for travelers who take early flight at Haneda Airport e.g. flight before 9:00am8. travelers cannot sleep well due to snoring from neighbour

Arrived late at Haneda Airport recently and as the hotel we reserved in Tokyo did not accept late night check-in, it seemed like a good idea to check into the First Cabin Haneda Terminal 1. My friends and I have never stayed in a capsule hotel before and this seemed like a great time to experience staying in one. Took the free shuttle bus from the international terminal to the domestic Terminal 1. The amenities available there were more than adequate. Had some late night snacks at their vending machines - food came out hot and unexpectedly delicious; maybe we were kind of hungry upon arrival! We were provided with a set of standard PJs and bath/face towels. The locker next to the bed was useful to store our valuables. The only downside was the ventilation within the cabin; was a little stuffy. Ear plugs are also provided if you are a light sleeper as you can hear snoring from the neighboring cabins as well as noises from your neighbors rummaging through their stuff/luggage. It was good that the reception staff reminded all those who checked in not to talk at the cabin area but only at the common lounge. Certainly a very memorable first time experience, worth visiting again.

Had a 12 hour overnight layover and this was cheap and perfect. Bed was hard and no frills as reported, tv is all in Japanese but does the trick and was pretty silent. Bathroom was great with free use of lotion, etc but didn't try the spa. Wifi worked great. I booked on their website and they charged my credit card onsite. You can get away without using any cash if you're on a layover (which is good because the atm minimums was US$80!Would def do this again. Also if you like green tea lattes this airport is heaven!!

Very convenient location, terminal 1, there is some restaurants outside, they have vending machines, but better options outside, shower is good they have private boxes and bath room. They give clothes and towed, bed was a little too hard, and pillow could be a little better, but I slept very good. DON'T forget to turn of your ring tone, you will wake everyone! Very cool experience!

location - convenient, free shuttle bus from international terminal to local terminalamenities - all shiseido brand, lots of amenitieshot bath and showers availablelounge with vending machines available in female section, there is also a room for you to have your phone conversation.food vending machines are also available at the public lounge next to the receptioncabin - small but ok for just an overnight stay, locker available next to your bed for storing your valuable stuff. poor air circulation inside the cabin, you will feel very warm and stuffy; and TOO much of noises from your 'neighbors'. definitely not for the light sleepers.

Arrived late into Tokyo and was flying to Sapporo the next morning, as opposed to sleeping in the airport we decided to have a shower and have a bed.The wash facilities are shared and the beds are hard but it was still a fun experience.I would not recommend this to anyone who is a light sleeper as there is only a curtain and everyone sleeps in the same area, you can hear what everyone is doing and you may be put near a snorer.

For those with a connection or early flight departing from Haneda, this is the choice. Specially if flying JAL, as it leaves from the same terminal. The first class capsule is not the typical capsule-style, as it has enough side space for luggage and standing. However, one cannot be a light sleeper as there will be noise from people coming and going, snoring, etc. Not my case as I sleep in any environment!Shower and bath facilities are very clean and well kept.

Me and my friend arrived quite late at night so we deiced to sleep at the airport and found this hotel on the Internet. Not so sure about capsule hotels as I'm a light sleeper but I have to say this hotel is above average. It's located in Terminal 1 but there's a shuttle bus running till midnight, taking about 10-15 minutes from International Terminal. Staff were friendly and English speaking. We booked 2 big rooms (6,300 JPY) so we had space to place our big luggage. There were a bath towel, face towel, pajamas, toothbrush and paste, slippers provided in the room. There were 2 shower rooms, hot water bath and a lot of sinks with shower gel, shampoo, lotion, hairdryer. No need to open your suitcase! There were also vending machines selling alcohol, drinks, snacks like onigiri and real food like rice curry. I didn't try that though. The only negative thing was noises. I could hear my friend next door and people coming in and out. Overall, it was a good short stay. A good start of our Japan trip :)

I have booked via e-mail provided by the website. Hotel staff are quick to respond. Business class cabin is ¥5000, first class ¥6000. For the sake of ¥1000, go first! You have space to keep your luggage for convenience!At International side. Last shuttle bus is at 00:40 at bus stop #7, before 00:00 there's a regular service every 5min at bus stop #0.Due to we missed all of it, the only option is taxi. Be aware tho, first taxi driver refused to take us, 2nd driver been kinda told by the guy who's in charge of taxi. He said he did not know the way, and the guy explained the route to him.Remember! They're located Domestic Terminal 1, Arrivals floor bus stop 8!!!Unfortunately our driver did try to ditch us at departure floor, we refused to get off as everything is locked! Unlucky for us a taxi journey which is supposed to be between ¥1200-1500, cost us ¥3000! You will see the board that says First Cabin Haneda, just ring the door bell and wait for member of staff to come and get you as everything is locked.Try to be prepared before you go in and take everything out of your suitcase! Everyone there are super tired so be considerate as you can even hear a penny drop!On your ID card and wrist band there's your locker key underneath the bed that you can stow all your valuables. In the room there's already slippers, PJ, toothbrush, towel, maybe remember to get ear plugs when you first check in! Also if you need travellers plug, ask them to borrow one, as they wouldn't allow to use your own.Use their lounge area to unpack the stuff you need in your suitcase, in there there's two vending machines for drinks and snacks, massage chair, charger point. By the time I'm ready to get washed, was about 2:30-3am, at that time, no one is in the bathroom! Just get washed when you arrive to avoid rush hour in the morning! They got shampoo, conditioner, body wash, face wash, toner, ALL by Shisheido =) they even got a hair straightener to use! Super impressed!!!!If you're shy, but still want to use the hot spring bath, go in at the unsociable hours like me as you have to be completely naked. Remember to bath yourself before you jump in!There's free wifi, code is behind your ID card, can be used anywhere even inside your capsule! Good speed too! :)I asked for wake up call, as they wouldn't allow you to use your phone in the cabin, poor lady must have stood on the door for like a good 3-4min! She just quietly call you, but would not step into your room or touch you. Yepp! I was knocked out, had a fantastic sleep and stay =) Don't think! Just book ;)

I guess you can't quite call First Cabin a 'capsule' hotel since we were not strictly in the traditional pods that capsule hotels are know for. We picked the 'First Class' cabins which were more spacious than the 'Business Class' cabins. The good:1) Communal shared shower stalls are offered or you could choose the usual sento arrangement of showering with everyone and enjoying the hot bath, which I did. A nice touch for a capsule hotel. In the vanity area, there were enough sinks, hairdryers and facial products for use. I could be wrong but I think this is standard for Japanese hospitality establishments - whether hostel or hotel. Still, this was something I appreciate. 2) We were told phones had to be set to silent or vibrate mode to avoid disturbing our neighbours. But despite that, not everyone adhered to the rule. I was awakened at 4am with an incessant ring tone from someone's phone several cabins down the corridor. Noise was definitely an issue. Because of the hollow fibreglass structure of the cabins, every close of a drawer or movement of bags could be felt/heard. Even if people spoke in whispers, you could hear. As such it was not easy to get a good night's sleep. Well between a night on a bench in the airport and the capsule hotel, I guess I'm glad I have the capsule hotel. For those who just want to tick off yet another box in the checklist of quintessential Japanese experiences, this is a novel experience and probably similarly comfortable as a hostel but now that I've BTDT, I wouldn't do it again.

the staff were very friendly and there was an english speaking staff member too. we booked via email provided by their website. the staff who answered our email was very helpful and even described how to reach terminal from international terminal step by step (including which bus stop and what time it stops, and incase you miss the lst bus there are other methods to reach them, etc) when we arrived the staff member explained to us that we can leave our valuables in a locker that is built in inside the cabin in which you sleep. the size of the locker (in the business cabin) was around 50x20x30 cm it could fit my handbag, camera case and a few other things. inside each cabin they provided a tooth brush with tooth past and lofa for body shower. in short ... they made our stay so comfortable even though it was a short stay (we were only there for 9 hours and had to leave on the second day to reach our hotel, since our flight arrived at 11:30 pm and our check in in the hotel at tokyo is at 3 pm the next day ;p) . i would highly recommend this hotel for late night arrivals who are exhausted and need a decent place to rest and refuel.

Does what it says on the tin.... but I have to say the staff were extremely helpful when I left my bag in the back of a taxi. They told me not to worry about it and miraculously it appeared less than an hour later. They will give you a wake up call if you need it - by tapping on your capsule door in the morning!Facilities are great - vending machines even have food! The internet in the common room was good, and they give free ear plugs. The large Japanese bath was really great too!Down side: I found the capsule rather stuffy - there was a switch for ventilation but it didn't do much. And the doors let in a lot of light - it's much better if you have an eye mask. Another down side is that it's based in the domestic terminal - and if you arrive after the last shuttle bus... it's nearly a JPY2,000 taxi ride from the international terminal which seems a little crazy.All in all, great service, great facilities, very useful.

I had an overnight layover and decided to stay at first cabin. After reading other trip advisor reviews I chose to stay in one of the larger cabins. My room had a bed small table, television, and a drawer under the bed to lock valuables in. It was 65.00 and I felt was well worth it, compared to staying in Tokyo. My room had plenty of space. They supplied slippers as well as a set of pjs. There is only one bathroom and was a ways from my cabin but it was ok. There are showers available as well as a vanity with a chair and everything you need in way of toiletries. Blow dryer, comb, toothpaste, toothbrush etc. there is also a large showering room with a pool or large soaker tub, but I was told no clothes are to be worn in it. There are also separate showers outside of this room that can be used. Everything was very clean. I arrived early for checking in, they kept my bag and looked up subway directions for me into the city. They did not speak much English when I was there but try very hard to help you.they are also willing to come and wake you up when you need to get up for a flight etc. they ask you not to use an alarm and put your phone on vibrate as not to bother other guests. I had no issue with noise from other people, everyone respected each other and tried to be quiet. I have never stayed in a cabin type place before but was really glad I chose to go this way. I had an early flight in the morning n it was so easy to just get up n go. Also the airport has a shuttle for free to take me to my departure gate.

All right so for a Capsule hotel it was the best one I have been to but it is still what it is: a capsule hotel. Noises from your neighbors and questionable guests, made me feel awkward half of the time. It is convenient that it is right in the Haneda Terminal 2 Domestic airport and you can take a free shuttle back to Terminal 1 if you have an international flight. All in all, I am satisfied with the stay. Don't expect too much quality though.

I stayed here in February 2015, after arriving at Haneda in the late evening. First Cabin is essentially an enlarged capsule hotel, with the convenience of an onsite airport location. It was about ¥5000/night. Just to be safe, find their website and make a reservation before you arrive. Upon arrival at the airport, it's not immediately easy to find FC, so check with the Information Desk; you may need to take a free terminal bus to the correct location. You'll arrive at a small, lobby-like area with a check-in desk, where you can leave your larger suitcases. Adjacent to this area is a large lounge with vending machines, TVs, free wifi, and power outlets. Good place to hang if you need to kill some time or send emails.After check-in, you proceed to the gender-separated lodgings, which reminded me of a long-term storage facility. The capsules are large enough to accommodate a full-size bed -- and some small suitcases -- just within the threshold of the pull-down barrier. The barriers do not lock, as with most capsule hotels, so leave valuables with the front desk. The capsules are tall enough that I can stand upright inside them (I'm 5'10"/1.78meter). It was surprisingly quiet, the only sound being other guests quietly shuffling around. Bathrooms and showers are in a separate area. Everything was clean,and all basic amenities -- toothpaste, toothbrush, razors, towels, hairdryer, etc -- were provided. The capsules have good wi-fi, a TV, and Radio.The whole experience was easy, clean, convenient, and great value. If I could transport this concept to LAX, it would be a revelation!Will def stay here again!
