Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

review_body: Very conveniently located cabin hotel right in the airport terminal. My flight was from the international terminal the next morning, which was a short bus ride away.I paid a bit extra for one of the first class cabins, which are slightly larger than the business class cabins and have room to stand up and put my luggage on the floor. There is a lockable drawer under the bed for storing valuables, as the cabins themselves do not lock.The communal shower area and bath were great. There are a few food options in the terminal so I easily found somewhere to eat dinner. A very comfortable night!

I had arrived at Toyko some eight hours ahead of my travel companion. A friend told me to book(in advance) First Cabin to have a good rest while waiting and I never regret doing.The first class cabin was comfortable. I could not wait to try out the large communal bath with its shower booth & powder room. Most of the necessities like bath lotion, shampoo, conditioner, pyjamas were provided. If you prepare well-ahead like me, there is no need to open the bulky luggage, which would create some noise. Must remember to turn your phone to silent mode as your neighbours would be annoyed.I tried their wake-up facility and was wondering how on earth they are going to wake-me up without making any noise. True to their words, at the specified time, a young lady in neat uniform appeared in my cubicle and signal to me. ( i should have pretended to sleep and see how she will wait me up).Overall the experience was good. I am not too happy with the lounge as it smells of heavy cigarette smoke. A separate smoking area is nearby. Although, we could buy food and drinks from the dispenser, it would be ideal if the hotel could instal plain water dispenser. Also, take note practically all the eateries around the hotel is close in the night.

Okay, you get into the Tokyo at 10:45pm and need a place to sleep for that night. The First Cabin is an excellent choice but not recommended for children. It's a large room with cubicles as sleeping spaces. Nothing is locked and the bathroom/showers are shared. There's even a nice spa! It's clean, quiet, friendly, and accommodating. I loved it!

we got an early flight at 6am so we decided to stay close to the airport the night before. Yes, all the photos are true to reality. I got the first class one which is absolutely spacious, and I got all our bags(2 baggage 2 Handcarry) in my room and still comfortable to move around. Plus, It's a double bed although each cabin is for single use.I am not that sensitive to noise, so able to get 3-hour sleep without any problem. But I was always afraid I would wake someone up for zipping and unzipping my bags. There is common room for people to chat and re-packing the bags, so juz make good use of it. Bathroom is fine for us, since we juz enjoyed the onsen hotel, so it kind of similar. The hotel is also being very considerate that they have 2 individual showers areas for those who are not used to public bathroom.Service is great, helpful, sincere and gentle. Since we are taking the shuttle at 0355 to international terminal, they will escort you out and wait until you got picked up. Probably the most personal service we received in our 3 hotels in Tokyo =]Recommended !

I arrived at Haneda late at night after the trains had stopped and decided to stay here till morning. The hotel calls its self a "cabin hotel" with a larger sleeping area than you will find in a capsule hotel. I decided to get the first class cabin which is big enough so I could have my luggage with me. If you get a regular cabin, your luggage will need to go in a locker or storage at the front desk. Men and woman are in separate areas so a couple can't get a cabin together. The bath room was communal type but had individual showers. Everything you might need is provided. Slippers, rode, toothbrush, and toiletries in the bathroom. Everything in the hotel was very clean The bed was hard like most beds you find in Japan and there is just a curtain separating you from hallway. The curtain does not lock. The only downside is that you can hear other people snoring. However, the hotel also provides earplugs for that. So if you are a person traveling alone and arrive at Haneda late, depart early, or just need a place to rest during a lay over, then this place is perfect. More airports need accommodations like this

I had a 15 hour stopover in Haneda, and my days of sitting in airports for that long are over my friend. I had not been to Japan, and let me tell you, the rumors are true, it's fricken expensive. I wanted a place within the airport where I could lie down and stash my luggage, and this was definitely the cheapest option, even compared to going to a capsule hotel outside the airport by the time you pay for transport etc. Day time bookings are available from 10am to 7pm and the cost is 800yen per hour for a business cabin and 1000yen per hour for a first class cabin. There's a free shuttle between terminals, so if you come on an international flight you must check out and take the shuttle to terminal 1 and it's on floor 1F, very easy to find and accessible to lots of delicious food courts and shopping. Food is not included, thee are a couple of snack machines but nothing very appetising.All the photos on the website are accurate, and the only difference between the two is that the first class has some floor space next to the bed, good if you want to take your luggage in with you. I left all my big luggage at reception and just took my small backpack into a business cabin and slept with it on the bed.The room has Japanese channels only, but has really good high speed free wifi which can stream off. The bed is wide, but very hard, I like a firm mattress but this one was one of the firmest I've slept on, this may not be comfortable for some people.The highlight was the shared bathroom with the hot pool. I have to admit I was totally ignorant to Japanese bathing culture and had no idea what to do, so for those in the same boat, you undress to naked in the changing area where the baskets are, and you go naked into the shared bathroom, where you take a seated shower in front of the mirror. Once you've finished showering/washing your etc then you can just hop into the hot tub, which is so amazing and really lovely and hot, none of this lukewarm business! I ended up going back for another one before I checked out. There is shampoo, conditioner, body wash, face wash, body lotion all supplied and all by shiseido (or at least that's what the bottles say).The staff wee extremely friendly and helpful and I have to say I would definitely stay there again. Only thing to bear in mind is that the roomss are single occupancy only, and men and women have separate areas, so if you're travelling in a couple you will not be staying together, you can only meet up in the shared lounge.(Or maybe that sounds appealing to you heh heh)

I have used this hotel several times now because it is very convenient for when I have an early flight, and because it is about half the price of other hotels near Haneda Airport.It is located inside Haneda Domestic Airport (Terminal 1, JAL) and is very easy to access.They have showers and a large bath which are always kept clean and tidy. They also have shampoo, conditioner, body soap, face wash etc.The staff offer a wake-up call service, which is very good if you want to be sure you get up on time!If you want to experience a capsule hotel with much more space, then I recommend this hotel.

I have stayed there when I had the late arrival. All the hotels were booked. I got the bigger unit in this place. It was a nice room! very spacious! The shared shower had individual stalls so you had enough privacy. Make sure to bring earplugs though because the rooms do not have actual doors and the walls are thin. This place is perfect for individuals but not suitable for a family because they don't allow small children. The rooms were divided by men and women's sections. So if you are traveling as a couple, you won't be able to share the same room. TL, DR: If you are traveling alone, stay here.

Due to an early flight and also wanting to experience something slightly resembling a capsule hotel, I found First Cabin on Trip Advisor. I arrived at Narita airport around 5pm on a Friday but had a flight the next morning at 6:20AM from Haneda to Ishigaki. After landing and getting my luggage and cell phone rental at Narita airport, I took the limousine bus from Narita to Haneda and checked in around 8:30pm. The ride was around 1-1.5 hrs. 1) Late arrival - I was surprised that when checking in the hotel was pretty empty at around 8:30, but the place got busier later in the night with new arrivals. After checking in, there were still some restaurants open until 10pm in terminal 1 so we were able to have a decent dinner, and there's a convenience store available as well. 2) Check in was straightforward. I can speak Japanese and also happen to look Japanese so I couldn't get a good sense of the English capabilities of the front desk staff as they continued to speak to me in Japanese even though I was speaking to my brother in English. You will get a copy of a map of the layout, instructions in English about the policies and also a cute illustrated instruction in English, Chinese and Korean on using the bathing area (i.e. you need to clean your body first before entering the bath). 3) You will receive a pass to get into the male and female cabin areas (separate entries for males and females) as well as a key for a big drawer under the bed if you opted for the first class cabin. For the smaller room, the drawer may be smaller. For me, I was able to unload some items I needed from my suitcase for the night and shove my carry on bag in there to lock it up. They can store large suitcases for you at the front desk if you are not comfortable leaving your suitcase outside of your cabin. You will be supplied headphones for watching tv. They will also ask you if you plan to charge anything. If so, they will give you an adapter to plug in your device to the electrical outlet. 4) If you are traveling with a member of the opposite sex the only area you can hang out together is a lounge area in the lobby due to the separate accommodations. I didn't mind since at most I would be there 8 hours, the majority of which would be spent sleeping or bathing. 5) A big draw for me was the bathing area. After a long flight from New York via Chicago, it was fantastic to be able to scrub the airplane ickiness off of me and soak in the tub. The ladies area has around 7 stations to clean yourself and the actual hot water tub can fit around 8 people in there. The ladies room has shampoo, conditioner, hair dryer, facial soap and lotions, q-tips, cotton squares, etc... They also supply you with optional shorts and shirt you can use for pajamas or lounging around, towels and toothbrush.6) Wake-up call: Someone will come wake you up for a wake up call as you are not supposed to use an audible alarm clock. I was a little paranoid about that but if you are able to set your cell phone on vibrate it's a good back-up.7) As a tip for the mens side, I asked that if possible they put my brother somewhere away from others since he is a loud snorer. They gave him a cabin (S15) which is in a corner and according to the map is not directly adjacent to another cabin. However, it's next to where people throw away their garbage and also along a path of a lot of foot traffic so apparently it was pretty loud for him with the noise from other people throughout the night.8) Convenience for morning flight - We took an inter-terminal bus to terminal 2 that took around 5-7 minutes from terminal 1 and ended up there around 5:30am. After passing security, it appeared that nothing was open until 6am including a Starbucks. There might be something open earlier than that before the security check point.9) If you are really particular about your mattress, the one I slept on was pretty hard which is my preference, but I am sure that that can be uncomfortable for anyone who needs a soft bed.10) I recommend if you are willing to spend a little extra, pay for a first class cabin. Having that little extra space is nice, especially after spending a long flight packed like sardines in economy class. For the cost, convenience and novelty, I recommend staying at First Cabin. If you know you are a light sleeper and the communal atmosphere doesn't appeal to you, then you are better off booking a hotel room near Haneda airport instead or at Terminal 2 (Tokyu Excel). The best way I can describe the experience is that it is like staying at a hip, upscale youth hostel with a bunch of well-behaved adults.

I was returning to the UK after some time in Japan on business and as my flight left early in the morning Iwanted to say as close as possible to the airport. This was one of the options presented by the company's travel agent. I must admit, I've always kind of fancied trying one of these places, so this seemed a great opportunity. I rocked up on a friday evening. First impressions were good and things continued to surpass my expectations on most fronts. Staff were friendly and helpful, the cabin was bigger (though I'm not very tall) and better equipment than I had thought, the bathroom facilties (which include a Japanese style hot bath) were excellent and the wifi was great. Only major downside was that it was fairly noisy throughout the night (guess this is why they provide free ear plugs). Would definitely recommend.

Taking a 7:30am flight the next day, so went to the airport the night before & stayed there. Stayed in the "business class" cabin which is basically a 3'x6' cubicle containing your bed, a little bedside shelf, a small locker, tv, light & nothing else. However when all you need is a bed to spend a night in the airport isn't that exactly what you need? It's also more spacious than the usual capsule hotel & I believe that's their selling point in their in-town properties. Bath is communal although they do have a couple shower cubicles probably for their international visitors. Definitely worth a try for the experience! Toilets are clean too. Access control is by an RFID pass card (like airport staffs lol) & although there are no storage for luggage, I have no problem placing it just outside my cubicle. No problem getting a drink from the vending machine. Staffs are only most happy to wake you up personally even in the middle of the night. Again it's barebone, but at 5000JPY & right in the terminal (not near, not beside, it's between the arrivals halls), I really wish it's available in airports worldwide.

As I was arriving at the international terminal at about 23:30 and departing from the domestic terminal early the next morning, the location was perfect. I paid 6300jpy for the 'first class' cabin. The bathroom facilities (for everyone) are great: showers, public bath, sauna, sinks, etc. They also have washing machines, a massage chair. They don't have a water fountain or a normal vending machine so think ahead. You can hear the person in the next cabin moving around, but I was not disturbed by noise in the night. I'll definitely stay there again.

Something special to me. Nice place they got sauna too. Staff there is friendly. Free shuttle bus to international airport every 5mins. I will recommend upgrade to business class only addition 500yen. You can get the bigger cabin. Will stay there again on my next visit.

If you are taking a late fight, it is advised to put a night at First Cabin in Haneda Airport, as there is no transport after 12.00 pm, only transportation avaliable is taxi and it is very very expensive.

This is a must try when in Japan. As it is near the airport, it makes a good stop over for the night before heading down to Tokyo the following day. Surprisingly the cabins are comfortable. The whole place is well kept and the staff very helpful and friendly.The bigger First class cabins have a lockable drawer under the bed which you can lock you backpack or small bag but not sufficient to stuff in anything larger then a backpack. Even my 60L backpack needed a bit of compacting to get it in the drawer. First Cabin Haneda is located in Terminal 1 and is quite some distance from Terminal 2. There is a free shuttle that takes you to the hotel. Just ask information counter and they will point you the way to the shuttle. To ensure there is an available cabin for you when you arrive, book online and let then know your ETA.

I stayed at First Cabin Haneda in a First Class Cabin in March. I made a reservation over three months prior at a rate of 5,900 Yen. When I arrived, First Cabin Haneda refused to honour this price, despite the fact I had written confirmation, and had re-confirmed the reservation and the price by email a few weeks before. They said they were very busy and so raised the price to 6,400 Yen. Very unprofessional.The staff spoke some limited English.As for the accommodations, the room was as described on the website: small, with an area to put my suitcase inside the capsule. There was a big TV, and a locking drawer under the bed for valuable. The bed was very very hard.The lounge had vending machines and free wifi.The washrooms were clean.This hotel was very convenient, but because they did not honour the reservation and over-charged me, I would look elsewhere for accommodations at Haneda.

Stayed twice in a week recently.First Cabin Haneda locates in Domestic Terminal 1( not too confuse terminal I / i for International terminal)After 12 hours flight from London landing in early morning at Haneda, I decided to have a rest for 4 hours (08:00am to 12:00pm) before I took next flight to Osaka.It was great that I was able to have a shower and big bath, have a quiet moment at the lounge and of course was able to lie down on the bed in First class cabin although I could not have a nap as it was busy morning time. (10:00am-12:00pm everyday is cleaning time)For a short rest, this is much better option rather than paying airport lounge facility near by.I booked to stay again in a week's time due to fly back to London the following morning.Again I chose to stay at First class rather than Business class as I had a big luggage and wanted to keep beside me. To stay this place as comfortable as possible, here's my tips (especially to travellers awaiting for a long haul flight following morning) :1. I requested to have a furthest end cabin which is the quietest section of all and the best choice if you want to have a decent rest. Staff were very obliging to accept my request.2. First class is the way to go if you are claustrophobic, it's more like a room. Also, If you want to keep your luggage, there's enough room to manoeuvre. If you are paranoid about security, bring a coiled bicycle lock like I did. You can tie your suitcase around bedside table leg. ( I did not have to use it as I felt safe enough and there is a lockable compartment under the bed)3. Alarm clock and mobile phone are not supposed to use in the cabin, but for example, if you want to wake up at 4:30am, request for a wake up call (this is manually done by staff) at 4:00 or 4:15 am at the reception(you have to fill a form upon check in), but you should put alarm clock at 4:30am for a peace of mind & just in case.On my first stay, I requested for a wake up call at 11:00am but staff forgot about it and eventually she came to me apologetically at 11:45am!( luckily, I was awake).Human error occurs and your airplane is not going to wait for you.4. Corporate to keep noise minimum for fellow exhausted travellers.Try to separate essential item for the stay(make up, clothes etc,) in a small bag,there is a changing room adjacent to female lounge.5. Give yourself time to have a bath and sit in the massage chair (100yen for 10 mins) before going to bed, it really relaxes you and be able to sleep nicely. Earplug(you can get at reception) and eye mask help,too.6. Most of the restaurants at terminal 1 close by 21:30 pm. Convenience store near by closes around 23:00pm.7. Bus stop (to and from International terminal) locates diagonally opposite to First Cabin Haneda on the same floor. Bus comes and goes every 5mins from early morning.Give yourself 15-20mins is enough time from check out to arrival of international terminal.Overall, it was very comfortable,convenient, clean & cost effective place to stay(for Tokyo) but you need to prepare yourself, you are not staying at conventional hotel. I did quite enjoy semi communal living arrangement! I felt very safe surrounded by likeminded travellers of all ages & the atmosphere was very relaxed.Will stay again when I fly to Haneda.

In the heart of airport, easy to find. Clean room, comfort bed with lots of facilities, such as pjamas, blanket, tv inside, headphone, etc. They have onsen inside :) really relaxing.. I love this capsule hotel. More than expectation. They also have food & drink machine 24 hrs. Love love :)

Curious wat to expect and it was a nice experianceYou dont have to be shy in the bathroom because everbody is naked and men and woman are seperatedBading in the onsen is very nice too do, also is there a sauna.Sleeping in the cubecle is also no problem and it is very silent thereFor a drink or a hot noodle soup jou go to the lounge where there are vending machineslJapan is also very safe, so dont worry about your stuff

Doing an overnight in a capsule is an interesting experience. After rolling up the 'garage door' style opening of your room, you see just how tight it's going to be. Then you dive in (there isn't any floor space - just the bed) and make the most of it.The hotel is about an 8 minute ride on the free airport shuttle from the International Terminal to Terminal 1. Just inside the drop off entrance, turn right diagonally and proceed to the 2nd hallway. Take the escalator up and you're there. There is adequate signage and the first impression is a good one - modern, clean and inviting. In addition to the front desk, there is a common room with tables and chairs, free WIFI, snack machines and 2 fee PCs. To the left of the front desk is the entrance to the women's only sleeping area; men's to the right. The women's area also has a private lounge area.Inside the capsule is a built-in lockable (they give you a key upon check-in) security box measuring 8"w x 30"l x 16"h. Also provided are disposable slippers, toothbrush and toothpaste, TV remote control, headphone jack, 2 electrical outlets and light switch. Sleepwear (top and bottom - one size fits - or doesn't - all) is provided and everyone walking around was wearing it. Like the hotel itself, it was comfortable. The shared bathroom has several sinks and hair dryers. There is a separate room with the toilets as well as a Japanese style bathing area. The showers had good temperature and pressure as well as liquid soap, shampoo and conditioner.Overall this was a very positive experience. The front desk will hold luggage you don't want to keep in your unsecured capsule, and the staff is friendly and helpful. The bed was adequate for the night, the price reasonable and everything was clean and well kept.I recommend this as a great stay if you arrive late or are making connections the next day. Very convenient and better than a lot of 'normal' hotels.

This hotel is situated at Terminal 1. When we arrived at Terminal 3, we took a free shuttle bus to Terminal 1 which was just 10 minutes bus ride. The shuttle bus has 5 minutes intervals until midnight. We emailed the hotel to confirm our ETA so that they won't cancel our reservation. Word of advice, book online at least 2 months prior to your visit since the hotel was always full. At 2am, there were at least 10 people checking in to the hotel. I'm a claustrophobic, but the cabin didn't overwhelm me. There's a curtain panel which you can close/open whenever you feel you need more air/space. Aircond was centralized. It was quite heaty for us but we couldn't do anything about it. I was quite surprised that the cabin had everything I needed. There's TV, locker to put your things (I put my handbag). And you can leave your luggage outside your cabin or at the corner and it's safe! I had quite a good sleep but my brother didn't. He said he could hear people snoring and that bothered him. Bathroom was clean and had everything - facial cleanser, hair dryer, manicure set - you name it. The onsen was nice so was the shower (good heat + pressure). All in all, I would recommend this hotel if you arrive late into Haneda.

Firstly, if you're a light sleeper, I probably wouldn't recommend First Cabin. First Cabin is a pod style accommodation with individual pods that have a slide down shutter for a door that does not lock, nor does it close 100%.The above is not intended to put anyone off, if you are interested in experiencing a pod, or capsule style hotel, please read on.We decided to stay at First Cabin after arriving on a late flight into Haneda. There is a free shuttle that goes between the International Terminal and Domestic Terminal 2 and then 1 which is where First Cabin is located.The bus was easy to find at the International Terminal (after exiting into airport, just follow the signs for the bus terminal), and my only concern was that Terminal 1 does close down after the last flight, but lucky for us the terminal was still open, and a quick question to a security guard showed that First Cabin was not far from the entrance inside the Terminal where the bus stop was.Check-in was easy. Males and females are of course segregated. You can leave your luggage (if it is large) just outside your pod, or if you are paranoid sleep next to it. We had booked the Business Class, which is smaller than the First Class pods. They are fitted out with a flatscreen television, a couple of hangers, clean sheets and a pillow, and small lockbox. You also get all the extras that you would get at any standard hotel, pyjamas, slippers, towels, toothbrush etc.The communal area is honestly better than what you would get in some average hotels. A small onsen, two single showers, a vanity area containing, cotton tips, hairdryers, mirrors, moisturisers etc. The showers had Shiseido shampoo, conditioner and body wash. Now, I know this is a standard brand for Japan, but for foreigners, it's a luxury.Inside the lobby there is a lounge area that has a few vending machines, and free wifi. The whole place was relaxed and clean.I am normally a restless sleeper, but in this instance I was exhausted and did not hear a thing. During this stay, it didn't seem like First Cabin was booked out, so access to amenties wasn't an issue. Overall I was quite pleased. I don't think it's the cheapest accommodation, but it certainly didn't disappoint.A good way to experience a pod hotel, even if it is not quite like the capsule hotels in the city, but newer and possibly much cleaner.Side note: the hotel felt quite safe and other travellers are polite and conscious of the noise.

I was in transit to the Philippines. Little did I know, I booked a ticket that had an airport transfer, so I had to go to Narita the next morning, but I was very tired so I decided to stay here and take a bus over to the next airport in the morning. I got off at the wrong terminal at the airport and a nice police officer took me all the way to the First Cabin front desk. They were very hospitable and had me checked-in very fast. They gave me a key to an already occupied cabin, however, so it was awkward opening up the shade and finding someone resting peacefully (oops). I went back to front desk and they apologized, but it was not that big of a deal to me. I got the larger cabin where you can actually walk in it. The smallest cabin has the bed right at the door when you open it...VERY SMALL. The next morning I was ready to check out and needed to purchase my bus ticket, but I had some trouble with using my visa. One of the receptionists helped me go to the bus ticket counter to purchase a ticket which took my card. I was very thankful for that as I was not prepared and tired because I didn't even sleep that night. Overall, it is a wonderful place to stay . It had just opened when I went so it was new. I will definitely go back again.

I stayed at this hotel twice - on the night before my early departure (stayed at first class cabin) & on the night of my late arrival (stayed at business class cabin). Very clean hotel with clever interior planning. Both first class & business class cabins were good, but I prefer paying a little extra ($10?) for extra room and stay at first class cabin next time. My only problem with this hotel was the noise issue. Although people don't talk inside the cabin area, you can hear everything else - neighbor's footsteps, luggage zipper sound, caugh, shutter door sound, and etc. Therefore, it's difficult to relax and fall asleep.

After the long fight arriving late and exhausted. I was disappointed that the front person (woman in her 30's I think) was sort of cold with no smile. She didn't say "thank you" when I checked out.I stayed on 8/24/13. This hotel has another bad review on a Japanese website (rakuten) about the same issue, I am assuming the same person was rude to them as well. It is just surprising to see that kind of service in Japan, especially at the airport (first point of Japan). Otherwise, the rooms and facilities were very very clean. I arrived after 12 am and besides the fact the bed was comfortable (capsule room) that I was extremely nervous not to make any noise. It costs over $50 to sleep for just 4-5 hours (you can't sleep right away due to being nervous and also need to get situated to sleep trying to maneuver around in a very small space without making noise). I am not sure I would use it next time since I could easily have slept at the airport (I saw many people sleeping on chairs). I rather spend $50 somewhere else. There is a shower room you can use at around $10 at the airport (not sure about hours). I recommend to just to use that and stay at the airport instead of paying $50 (plus taxi fair of $13 to get there - bus service stops after 11:45pm or so). I paid over $100 since I have more than one person in my party. I was not happy when the front lady (same lady who checked us in) didn't say "thank you" or anything when we left. She knew I was leaving but went on doing her chores, ignoring us.The good customer service goes a long way. If the front desk lady was extremely pleasant, I would consider using it again just to feel welcomed and appreciated which always makes traveling a positive experience.

Checked into the hotel after an early morning arrival flight just past 6am. Stayed at the first class cabin which had space to put the luggage bag that cannot be stowed into the secured draw out storage under the bed. Even though the doors cannot be locked, it was very private because the "shutter door" could be drawn almost all the way down. The toilets and showers are all shared facilities but extremely clean. Also had proper shampoo and body wash provided. Many brightly lit dressing tables to put on makeup and dry / style hair properly. Most importantly, it is located AT the airport, no need for any shuttle buses. A great convenience if arriving early morning, like I did. Or catching a very late flight out.

This is just to catch your flights. The reputation for this hotel should be only from this point. Indeed, normal hotel around Haneda is far to catch early morning flight or not reasonably expensive. The room is just small. There is a hotel type "capsule hotel". This hotel is one of them. But the hotel type is really, really tiny. It is only for sleeping. In comparison with them, this is much bigger. For me, it was enough space. Cleanness is, not clean but not dirty. But bed is clean. Of course, there isn't individual bath. Only public bath. But not bad. You can use body soap and shampoo. There is shower and big bathtub though for common use. It is same with "sento" http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sent%C5%8DStuffs attitudes are very good and friendly.And you can ask free shuttle bus to international terminal even when shuttle train between terminal 1 and international terminal isn't running. But you need to ask reservation before 4 o'clock. Just convenience is the value of this hotel with reasonable price. But you need ear pad for good sleep against others' noise.

Flying in from Detroit for my first time in Japan, I wasn't sure where to stay. I chose this location solely based on ease of finding not speaking Japanese and arriving at almost midnight. The location is less than 10 minutes from the international terminal. Staff were helpful. The First Class room was significantly bigger than I expected although the Business Class was also at least twice as tall as I had expected. The other guest were all considerate, the facilities were spotless, and a soak in the spa was an unexpected surprise after a long day on the plane. I would definitely stay here again if traveling through this airport.

review_body: This is based on the ladies cabin. We stayed a night in Business Class Cabin due to late night flight and had booked in advance. If you arrive from other terminals, watch out for the last shuttle bus that will take you to terminal one where First Cabin is. Terminal one is not 24hrs and will be closed shortly after midnight. The shuttle bus drops you directly in front of the small 'door' of First Cabin where there is an intercom for you to call for the First Cabin staff to open the door for you. But we reached before the terminal closed, so we didn't have to make use of that.It does seem like a maze at first as eveything was painted black and the doors looked the same. Everything was on the same floor. But there are enough signages to bring you to where you want. And of course, the male and female are separated. There's a cloth roller blind to close every cabin but it doesn't close fully to the floor. Rows of cabin faces each other and it's not sound proof. Now you get idea how it's like so don't complain about the noise. The japanese are courteous enough to keep their noise level low so check yours. Be smart and bring your ear plugs. I had my ear plugs on for a pretty good short rest. The cabin was clean. There's a safe in each cabin. You have to use their in-house adaptor and not allowed to use your own. We left our lugguage outside our cabin just like everyone else and this was convenient, but it was noise pollution because everyone could hear when you start zipping and unzipping your lugguage. Comfy sleeping wear, slippers and towels are provided too. All very clean. There's also hanger provided and you could hang your clothes in your own cabin. The bed wasn't that hard. There's tv too in your own cabin and you use the headphones provided if you want to watch tv. There's a ledge along the bed in your cabin where you can place your nitty gritty eg watches, hp, etc.. There are 2 private western shower room and also a public bath. All amenities are provided. There's also make up room, and everything a lady would need is provided, cotton pads, cotton studs, hair curler, hair dryer, tissue, etc... As usual, everything is clean. And remember to clean up after use too. Every japanese does that. There's vending machine for drinks, snacks and even hot meal within the hotel. There's also a vending machine that sells all-in-one cream. Comes in pretty cases but expensive. A good choice if you need to transit, have early flight or late night flight. More than you could ask for. Thumbs up!

Two nights ago I had an overnight transit at Haneda and ended up staying here. I ponied up for the larger First class cabin, and found the increased space to be well worth the extra. Unlike the poster before me, I found the room to be clean with no smoke smell. The locker functioned well enough to store my most expensive items, and the bathrooms and shower rooms were all sparkling clean. The only thing I would recommend would be to book in advance if you are female or if there is one in your group; there was a couple who came in without a booking the same night I was there, not knowing that it was gender-segregated; there was room for the husband but not the wife. There's no restaurant, but the vending machine in the lobby dispenses hot food, which is the most I'd expect of a capsule hotel, even a nice-looking one like this. At that price (much less than the Excel Tokyu) and location, it can't be beat. Don't come here expecting a full-service experience and you'll be golden.

The place looks nice in the outside, but terrible in the inside. You can smell the smoke from the smoking room and there is no restaurant in the hotel unless the terminal is open. The hallway smells awful and the room is very small even in a First Class Room. You cannot lock the doors or have any security. You can hear what goes on in the hallway. The bathroom and the sink is disgusting and you have to share literally everything except your bed in the room. I do not recommend it at all.

The hotel is at domestic terminal 1. From international, take the shuttle bus near Air Lawson to bus stop no 8. It is the second stop. The first stop is at domestic terminal 2. Check in process was smooth. The capsule rooms were small but cosy. The bed was comfortable but you don't have much space for luggage unless if you booked the first class room. The cleaniess is great especially the bathroom and toilet. Here is where I first experienced the famous Japanese toilet, hahaha.

Love the place, inspite of the loud snores amonth the neighboring capsules, but ones inside ou can sleep peacefully.Toilet and bathrooms are all clean, like brand new clean.Would have appreciated if they provide water dispenser for drinking, although the tap water is relatively safe.Price during golden week of their business class cabin is 5200yen.Another suggestion would be to increase the wind ventilation inside the capsule, since it is quite stuffy, if the TV and lights are turned on at the same time.

I stayed in this hotel just before flying back home. I wanted to try a capsule hotel and this one really exceeded my expectations. It is a very quite and welcoming place. The shared toilette are very clean and of a very high standard. They are also stocked with products by the high-end brand Shiseido(!!) and there is a small spa insite. The bed was relatively comfortable. You do not get as good sleep as people keep coming in and out throughout the night but it is really convenient to be able to get a few hours of sleep/rest before an early flight. They provide you with pijamas, two towels, slippers and a toothbrush and toothpaste. You hardly had to open your luggage! There should be a place like this in all the airports in the world.

My husband and I booked it with the intention to start our vacation the Japanese way, i.e. the famous capsule hotels found only in Japan (as ar as we're concerned!) as well as to get a good night's rest before heading to Tokyo early next morning as we reached Haneda late at night. It was a bit pricey but we were glad we booked it - we really rested well and was full of energy for the next day's itinerary.The capsule rooms were small but cosy although a bit hot for me as I couldn't find a switch for the aircond haha. The bed was comfortable enough but would pose a problem if you are claustrophobic. You don't have much space for luggage but you have the option of 1) leaving your luggage with the front desk; or 2) bringing it with you and placing it outside your capsule. Btw, you won't be able to lock your 'room' but you will be given a kep for a small locker for valuables. They also provide you with comfy cabin wear and slippers and toiletries, so basically you have pretty much everything needed for a night. There is a public bath area (there is a tub in there but you will have to strip), 2 shower rooms (ladies; I don't know about the guys) and a spacious and wonderful make up area!! Oh, and of course, toilets. They provide you with everything! - shampoo, conditioner, body wash, facial wash, curlers, hairdryers, huge mirrors with great lighting - obviously you can see why I love it and it is obivous Japanese people take much care of how they look. :) You also find a vending machine for body creams in the ladies' lounge! But bear in mind that you have to be very quiet once inside the room areas.They have wonderful vending machines - even more so for our very first night in Japan - drinks, body creams, even frozen food! So you can have your midnight snack anytime you want to. Then there is a comfortable lounge for you to eat and hang out - this is next to the front desk, so if you are going with the opposite sex, this is the place for you to meet. There is also wifi throughout, so no worries about getting disconnected.All in all, we really enjoyed the experience and are really greateful for a good night's sleep, even more so after seeing people sleeping on the airport chairs. We paid RM170 per pax and do bear in mind that it is located outside the international terminal, so you'll have to hop on the free shuttle bus for a short ride to the terminal 1 Would definitely be back! :) I love Japan!

I had a flight out of haneda at 6.30am and rather than spending $200 for a taxi I decided to spend the night here. I opted for the first class cabin, which was only slightly more expensive and had enough room for my luggage as well. Very clean and comfortable place. I'm usually not a big fan of shared bathroom facilities but the facilities here were so clean it wasn't a problem at all. They even have a small Japanese onsen (bathhouse) which I found useful. Staff were extremely nice and friendly and they escort you to catch the shuttle bus to the international terminal which run at regular intervals.

this is a great option for early flights out of haneda, especially if combined with a late night arrival. it's easy to get to via airport shuttle. would recommend making reservations as it seems to get pretty crowded. first class type cabin is nice for luggage and a little more space to move around. they will hold luggage at front without fee. lights get a little warm in the cabin but they can be dimmed. there's also an air control switch, which helps a little. earplugs are helpful since people are milling about throughout the night. eye masks will help block out light that comes from the corridors since the sliding curtain doesn't go all the way to the ceiling. the rooms come with loungewear, toothbrush/paste, slippers, bath and face towel. locked drawer below bed. beds are little firm and plastic-y feeling. blankets are heavy and a tad warm. free wifi. there are only vending machines in the lounges but there are a lot of restaurants in the airport.bathrooms have a toilet section and shower area with 2 stalls and a sento room with squat showers. facewash, shampoo, conditioner, lotion all feel good quailty. coin laundry. first cabin works cause people follow the rules. no talking, no phones, alarm clocks etc in the cabins. there are lounges and phone rooms for socializing. it didn't feel like my safety was compromised at all. the last airport shuttle goes around 12:05am and there is one shuttle at 3:55am and 4:25am before running regularly starting at 5am. cabs don't seem hard to catch otherwise.

I stayed over for a night as I was arriving late into Haneda. I didn’t want to deal with stress of missing the last train or navigating Tokyo in the middle of the night. I also wanted to try staying at a capsule hotel, though First Cabin is more a designer capsule hotel. Full amenities are provided including pyjamas, headphones (for first class cabin), lockable drawer, shoe horn, adaptor (which you have to use), toothbrush (a bit too firm for me), free wifi. There a common lounge where there is a smoking room and a telephone room so you can take your calls without disturbing others. Of course vending machine where you can get food. Showers and soaking tubs are great after a long flight. The bed was comfortable and I had a pretty good sleep. You can hear others snoring or farting and the nosiest time is about 4 a.m. when people get up to catch the early flights out of Haneda.

Spent the night here recently when I had a late arrival with a morning departure. It didn't make sense to try to find somewhere in town when First Cabin was so convenient. It was very easy to find, incredibly clean and efficient and quite comfortable. I would definitely recommend it to someone for an overnight experience

An alternative option instead of staying at a hotel, First Cabin is a capsule style private room located in Terminal 1 of Tokyo Haneda Airport, perfect for early morning flights, but also available for hire for a few hours, or day use, if you have a long wait for a connecting flight.I opted for the First Class Cabin of 4.2 square metres, instead of the Business Class Cabin of 2.5 square metres. Divided into men and women areas, once inside I was pleasantly surprised to find a modern clean space with rows of cabins. My cabin Y08 had a double bed, small table and 32' flat screen TV. On the bed towels are folded, headphones for watching TV (so you don't disturb others), a dental kit, and branded pajamas to wear. Even a special adapter is supplied for charging your electronics as others are strictly prohibited due to fire regulations. There is also a safety box for storing valuables under your bed since cabins do not have a door and do not lock for safety reasons, instead pulling on the vertical shutters ensures your privacy.Extra facilities include PC stations, battery charger for mobiles and laptops, lounge with a separate smoking room, vending machines that offer soft drinks, alcohol, snacks, bread and even noodles. A self-service laundry, bathhouse, showers, and a coin operated massage chair which I especially enjoyed in the spa area.First Cabin is a well thought out experience and am very impressed by its function and facilities, a great value stay with all the amenities of a hotel, in a cabin style room conveniently located within the airport terminal.***Note: First Cabin is located in Terminal 1 of Tokyo Haneda Airport, not Terminal I (i) the international terminal. When I left First Cabin at 4:30am found myself locked-in the domestic terminal, thanks to a security guard I was escorted outside and luckily found the only passing vehicle, a taxi, and took the short ride to the international terminal in time to catch my very early morning flight.

I stayed here during a layover to catch an early morning flight to Osaka. My room was immaculately clean, so were the showers and restrooms. The hotel was surprisingly quiet considering there is only a light screen instead of a door for privacy on each room. Downside was the check in time at 7:00. I was able to check in early at an extra cost of about 2000 yen. Not the most comfortable place to stay if flying in from overseas, but certainly convenient if you're catching an early-morning flight.

Overnight guests cannot check in before 1900h. With that said, my companion and I took our snail's pace from Narita Airport through SkyTree complex for early dinner and then crawled our way to Haneda Airport. Checked in at 2030h and checkout by 0500h (flight at 0655h). Very efficient concept of sleeping quarters with a sliding privacy shade. They segregate by gender, possibly because of the open locker room style washrooms. Staff very shy to use English; however, they are more comfortable speaking Mandarin and Korean. Best compartments are adjacent to the larger rooms (I was in W6) because they are further away from the high traffic areas towards the washrooms/exit. Ventillation was sub-par. The lightbulb emits a lot of heat that is not dissipated fast enough. The privacy shade does not close all the way, leaving a gap for air to flow into cabin. If you have smelly shoes, please be courteous enough to enclose them in a plastic bag. The odors seep into cabins easily. The washroom is a typical Japanese style locker room. Be sure you're thoroughly washed and rinsed clean before entering the soaking tub. Very few food options at the airport terminal by 2100h. Be sure you have your own beverage (vending machine not cheap). OBTW, the provide pajamas... sadly, not the cotton kind that will absorb sweat easily. Also, the women's bathroom has all Shishedo cosmetic products for communal use.

review_body: We booked an overnight stay at First Cabin because we were arriving late at night and didn't want to have to worry about missing the subway/bus and ending up spending a fortune on a taxi to town. So for that reason, First Cabin was a good choice, as it's in the Haneda airport itself. We took the free shuttle bus from the International terminal to Domestic terminal 1, where the hotel is. There are separate areas for men and women. The business class rooms are small and completely occupied by the bed with no space for luggage, which they took care of at the reception. There's no actual door, just a sliding screen that can't be locked. Because of that, it was quite noisy, but the bed was comfy enough for me to get some shuteye. In the room you'll find a small lockable safety box, power points, individual air-conditioning and a TV with headphones. Pyjamas, bedroom slippers and towels are provided. The shower and toilet area is clean and well-equipped with Shiseido toiletries. Basically everything you need in transit. You can also stay here by hour but no advanced booking is allowed.

First Cabin hotel is a neat idea. The rooms are small but what you would imagine a first class room in an aeroplane might look like. Think of it as a bridge between a capsule hotel and a regular Japanese hotel room (which are also small).The hotel itself is located in DOMESTIC terminal 1. I arrived at international terminal 1 and thought it would be easy to find but actually, I was in the completely wrong place. Though it's easy to take the terminal bus, which runs from about 4am in the morning.Men and women are separated so if you are a couple or family, you'd have to split up! Though I think this hotel is mainly for salarymen or those who arrive early/depart early, like I did.There are two types of stays:Overnight stays, which you can reserve in advance, checking in from 7pm.Day rooms, from a minimum of 2 hours. Just walk in and check for free rooms.I used a day room for 3 hours as my flight arrived at 5am and I wanted to shower after my 12 hour flight and perhaps get some shuteye.On my departure, I had a 6am flight and transport from Tokyo to Haneda is a little difficult at 4am. So rather than risk anything, this is a relatively cheap alternative to booking a proper hotel nearby. The added convenience is this hotel is directly in the terminal!There are also two types of rooms:First class: I stayed in this, which fits a bed and has some floor space for your suitcase.Business class: Literally, the room fits the bed and that's it. So if you have a big suitcase, I don't think you'll be able to fit it in. I recommend booking the first class cabin which doesn't cost that much more.On checkin, the staff spoke some English and you fill in a form and let them copy your passport as usual. They show you to your cabin and point you in the direction of any facilities. They give you an entrance card, which gives you access to the room area and a key which is your locker key.First Class cabin: There's a TV and they provide headphones so you don't disturb other guests. Under the bed is a lockable draw, which you could fit a small backpack into plus any other valuables. They supply some pyjamas (shorts/T-shirt), slippers, towels and a toothbrush. That's about it. There is no door. Rather, it's a sliding screen which is not lockable. Magnetic latches close the shutter and stop it faffing about. There's a small gap (approx 20cm) under and above the screen so you can see people walking by and hear any noises. Because it's basically open, you can hear people zipping their suitcases or dropping things. Annoyingly, people will have different flights to catch and hence, you'll probably hear alarms going off throughout the morning. There's not much you can do about it really except use some earplugs or listen to your ipod.The rooms are individually air conditioned, in that you can choose off-medium-full, for the ventilation speed. I found it was a little warm but OK in reality. Not hot and humid like it is in mid August! Bed itself is very hard and pillow is a small one. There are several power sockets in the walls (2 flat pin ones) and one LAN (RJ45) port. There is no free wireless in the area. So if you have a laptop, it needs to have a LAN port (which my macbook air doesn't) and you'll need to supply your own network cable. No internet if your device only supports WIFI.Other than that, the toilets are like regular public toilets, except you need to take off your regular slippers and use the special toilet slippers - if you don't know what this is, you'll soon understand if you visit any traditional hotels in Japan.Separately, the bathroom is fairly large and has several wash basins. There were only 3 or 4 other people when I used it but I suppose at peak periods there could be over 25 guys at once (no idea about women's side..). There were only 2 showers that I saw. These are walk in showers with frosted doors, so some privacy. Soap, shampoo is provided. There are baskets outside the shower to leave your stuff in it. I took my towel in with me into the shower and hung it on the door handle since there were no hooks. But you risk getting the towel wet. I think the Japanese just stroll around naked. There was also a communal hot bath but I didn't use it.There's also laundry machines should you need to wash any clothes.By the reception there are vending machines and computers to access the internet. Overall, basic facilities but on the whole clean and serves its purpose. Probably every airport should have one of these!
